Reviews.Title: Completely failed on very first day
Reviews.Author: Dave Pacheco
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera while on vacation to take on a kayak trip and to the beach.  It worked fine for a few hours on the kayak trip, and I'm reasonably pleased with the hundred or so photos I got out of it.  But that afternoon at the beach, it stopped working in a pretty nasty way: when I turned the camera on, it would immediately take a photo, without having pressed the shutter release button at all.  Then when I did press the button, it wouldn't take a photo.  It seems that the shutter release button had shorted out.  I tried rinsing in fresh water, letting it dry out overnight, etc., but it never recovered.As far as I can tell, I followed all of the instructions around keeping the camera waterproof.  There was never any water in the battery compartment or anything.  It never got more than a few inches beneath the water's surface, nor did I drop it in the sand.  So I don't know what happened, but it totally failed after just a few hours of what I would consider normal use for this camera.

Reviews.Title: Fun but Complicated
Reviews.Author: Hiker66377
Reviews.Content: First off let me say I'm very pleased with the FinePix XP50.CONS:- It's a water proof camera but it warns you not to use it around sand and water. So while it is water and mudd proof, it's NOT very sand proof.- It uses a NP45A battery and I normally like AA rechargeable cameras- It doesn't come with a car charger adapter (AC only)- You  have have to go into the settings menu a lot- The camera has a lot of features that are tricky to figue out ( you'll probably want to read the manual to get the most out of the camera)- Videos record as MOV- it doesn't float ( but not many do)PROS:- 14 mp picture are awesome. Point and shoot and crop later.- Takes great under water pictures/movies- 2.7 LCD is super bright so you can see your picture outdoors, in bright sun light, after you take them. People that use my camera comment on how nice you can see the screen outdoors- Easy to put in silent mode- Water and shock proof- Ton of mode settings so you can adjust lighting and speed automatically- 360 auto pamaramic feature. Press button and just slowly turn in a circle. It auto joins them into 1 picture that shows like a movie on the camera VER COOL for things that are to big to capture with a picture- You can use their software to upload directly to Youtude and Facebook (after you copy the pictures)You need a fast SD card,  Class 4 (44x) or faster for fast picture taking and recording HD videos. Battery only takes about 250 pictures or so. I took it on a day trip, took a few short videos, 190 pictures and reviewed the pictures a lot and it lasted all day. You can get a NP45A car chager with a battery for about $10-15. I also have a float wrist strap for it ($10).So all and all I really like the camera. I take a lot of outdoor pics so the ultra bright LCD is a big plus! 14mp let's you crop wide photos and still have great image quality. The menu is frustrating some times but you get used to using it.I recommend it for the outdoor pictures taker even if you don't plan to use it under water. Not having to worry about getting it wet or dropping it is nice!

Reviews.Title: Lives up to promises, perfect if this isn't your "primary" camera...
Reviews.Author: Red

} } } Length:: 0:10 MinsI do want to add that expectations from this camera make a huge difference on how satisfied you will be with the performance. It really is a matter of making the right comparison of apples to apples. So I'll compare this to other waterproof camera methods, and other waterproof cameras in this price range. I've also uploaded a bunch of photos taken at max resolution and a video recorded at full HD 1920p 30fps. The video was taken on a foggy and overcast day. The actual quality of photos and video won't show up correctly on Amazon but it should give you at least an idea of what to expect.From a hobbyist's perspective:I had my reservations about this camera but purchased it anyway because I like the design and orange color. Most waterproof point and shoot cameras currently on the market are a little on the bulky side, expensive, and have major problems with leakage (faulty latches over battery/sd card doors). This being an upgraded model comes with a safety lock that keeps you from accidentally opening the latch and letting water in...a nice plus. It is very difficult to unlatch the XP50 door accidentally since both "locks" have to be unlocked or relocked -in the proper sequence- to open/close the door. I wonder if some of the reviewers may have confused this camera with its near identical predecessor which had only one, non-locking latch.When researching for a waterproof camera solution, I have tried the following:1. Pouches ie. Dicapacs - Vinyl pouches that zip closed basically like putting your camera in a super-Ziploc bag. These for the most part work well and have never failed on me. They are relatively inexpensive and universally sized. However, controls are often difficult to operate or access, they make your equipment extra bulky and difficult to hold, zoom lenses aren't always compatible, and unless you purchase a really good quality version you may end up with fuzzy pictures because of the not so crystal clear (or scratched) pouch. You also have to be very careful to keep the insides immaculately clean and dry, even the smallest amount of moisture will cause the pouch and your camera lens to fog.2. Custom underwater cases made specifically for certain camera models (ie. compact Canon cameras) - Work extremely well, allows complete access to controls and functionality of camera features, enhances underwater photography. More often than not these cases are well made with latches all around and heavier duty rubber seals. They look really cool too. Unfortunately they are very expensive, model specific, and add weight to your gear. If you have an older model, favorite camera of yours, you may be able to find a custom case for it for $20. I just saw one for a Canon Elph 3MP camera (that's old!) for $20 on Ebay. If you can't find a used one expect to pay upwards of $150-$200.3. Various dedicated underwater point and shoot cameras..both disposable and non-disposable. There is a large price range for them so it's really a matter of balancing features, purpose, and what you're willing to spend. There are many pros and cons but too many to list for each model I've tried. So below is what I think of the Fuji XP50.Design:Personally I think it looks quite attractive. I purchased the orange because it gives it a rugged, outdoorsy, look. Chrome accents all around and rubber surround the screen and anyplace your hands might need a little extra grip. There's a nice extra wide shutter button, toggle zoom, and the usual menu/record buttons on back. If you have used point and shoot digital cameras before, then you will find that buttons and menu are pretty self-explanatory. No instruction manual needed. There is only one door, with two locks on it covering the battery, sd card, and hdmi/usb. Perhaps my only concern would be the durability of the rubber seal inside this door. If I had to describe it, it sort of looks like a thin small rubber band and it's the only thing keeping the water out of your camera. As with all "waterproof" camera solutions, I ALWAYS test before I put to actual use. In the sink, in the bathtub, at the pool, in the rain, whatever you need to do to make sure there are no surprises later. I kid you not, I've actually tested cameras in jacuzzis just to see how well seals would hold up. (Not that I am advocating this to people who buy from stores with strict return policies.) I also rinse off the camera EVERY time it's been in or near chlorine, saltwater, etc.Performance:There is a slight lag from pressing the shutter button to taking a photo. Indoor pictures were mediocre.... Photos were consistently grainy, dark, and blurred. The flash helps a lot for subjects that are close, but not for subjects on the other side of the room (very dark). I could see that this would be an automatic deal breaker for some people.However, this camera really is marketed for outdoor use. There is no mention of it's ability to take photos indoors or in low light on the carton. Not that it couldn't, but it just wasn't designed with that in mind. (Most cameras boast about their sensitivity to low light). As an outdoors camera, it works pretty darn well. Color reproduction was very good and photos (even viewed on a 20" screen) were very acceptable.I'm also very happy with the optical zoom (5X) and the digital zoom. Though pictures come out slightly grainy as expected, I can take photos of houses over a half mile away. Many cameras, even higher end ones, take blurry, unidentifiable photos on digital zoom.The built in photo enhancement settings (ie. scenes, macro, 360 deg panoramic, underwater, landscape, etc.) also seemed to do a pretty good job of helping me achieve the look that I wanted in my photos. There are also settings for movie trimming/joining, red eye removal, in camera cropping and rotate, and marking for upload to facebook and youtube. I've also found that continuous focus modes (both movie and still) as well as facial recognition bonuses to have. I've taken self portraits of myself at arms length and pictures came out very sharp and my face, though off center, is very much in focus.Movies came out extremely nice at Full HD 30FPS 1920p and we have viewed these on a 20" monitor in HD quality. It was impressive coming from a $100+ camera. The microphone is located on the front of the camera and speaker on the side. Speaker is pretty good and you can hear a voice clearly on it. The mic will pick up sounds clearly if you are in front of it, but speaking from behind the camera results in a muffled recording. Though I'm not happy about the usb cable they provided (wish they would have included a micro hdmi) since I rarely hook up cameras to pc's.Summary:Overall a good buy for the $100 dollar range. I paid about $140 and also received an 8gb sd card, a floating wrist strap, a neoprene arm strap, a regular wrist strap, a camera case with neck strap...a certificate for a free custom photo book, I'd say I got a great deal.It is not the best waterproof point and shoot but it's definitely not the worst. It has so far been a solid performer and durable for me, but it's hard to say if there are just a lot of lemons out there or only people who have lemons post reviews because many have stated theirs crapped out on them the first day. So far my camera is living up to what was promised. For the record Nikon makes a similarly priced waterproof camera that is humongous and has horrible reviews. Just goes to show how little effort is put into this niche market.There are definitely models out there that combine a good indoor and outdoor camera in one but you will spend 2 to 3 times more. What I enjoy most is that this relatively low cost camera is just used for my outdoor activities and as such, I can "manhandle" it a little more than I would my $1000 DSLR...heck I wouldn't even manhandle a $200-$300 Canon point and shoot...but I'm less worried about my equipment and having more fun on the jetski with the Fuji XP50. I also want to mention that this is not my primary camera. I use this for anything I can't (rather, shouldn't) do with my DSLR.

Reviews.Title: Took it back
Reviews.Author: RNS
Reviews.Content: I was not very happy with this camera.  Our last point-and-shoot died, and we needed another "pocket" camera.  Without doing much market research, I went to the local big box store to look at what they had in stock.  They had 3 waterproof/shockproof cameras, and I picked the FujiFilm Finepix XP50.  The first day we used it - no real "problems" other than blurry pictures and an apparent slow write-time to clear the buffer to take a second picture.  The second day we used it, I put it in my bathing suit pocket & waded around with it for a bit (no more than 2 1/2 feet under water at any time).  A couple of shots came out fine, but then I started seeing white on the rear screen & in the images.  A quick check showed water inside the lens housing.  I quickly took it to the bank & dried off & opened it to find water in the battery/memory card compartment as well...  Camera was less than a week old, no dirt/hair/apparent problems with seal, but there was a leak somewhere.  Between the poor image quality & the leak, I took it straight back to the store without going home to change out of my swimsuit.  I replaced it with another brand...

Reviews.Title: must be a great camera
Reviews.Author: scott
Reviews.Content: found this camera on the bottom of a river in Texas, color caught my eye, so I pulled it out, wiped off the silt, and and turned it on. it is fast and effective, takes great pics and the battery lasts a long time. According to the date stamp it had been under 2 feet of water for 3 days.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the price.
Reviews.Author: Leon Caswell
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for vacation.  Used it in both salt and fresh water for three consecutive days.  Easy operation, very good battery life, and better than expected image quality.  Shot quite a bit of underwater video at 1080p and was very impressed.  Definitely recommend.

Reviews.Title: Good rugged camera for the price
Reviews.Author: txmama "txmama"
Reviews.Content: I found this camera to be good for the price you pay.  I had orginally purchased the Lumix by Panasonic with was about $100 more expensive but bugged out after just 5 days.  So, I picked this up as a quick buy on vacation to replace the Lumix.  I was happy with the photos for the most part.  This camera is much more sensitive to what shooting mode you have it in with regards to the quality of photos that you end up with. For example, Zoomed in photos can turn out blurry with slight movements if you don't have it set on sports mode.  I have not tested out the underwater or shock proof claims yet and probably won't given the feedback I've seen on this and other models claiming to be water proof.  It is water resistant for sure, can get splashed etc which is good enough for me.  I plan on taking it on scouts outings etc and it being rugged is helpful. For only $170, I think this camera is a good deal.  I just wouldn't test it's limits that's all.  Overall am happy with the purchase.

Reviews.Title: Worked for us!
Reviews.Author: L. Carter
Reviews.Content: A few days before we left for Hawaii, we decided to buy an underwater digital camera instead of using disposables.  We payed about $150--we didn't have enough time to order one, so had to find something that was in stock somewhere nearby.  Honestly, after a week on Kauai and 3 snorkling adventures, my husband and I both feel like we got our money's worth.  The pictures from our first two snorkling trips aren't great quality, but that was due to poor underwater visibilty, not the camera.  It can be hard to aim well for your shot, but again, that isn't really the fault of the camera.  The surf was moving us AND the fish around, we're wearing diving masks which are fogging up on us, etc.  We STILL got a lot of really neat shots, and some video footage as well.  If you're in the ocean (or other moving water) expect some shaking.  If you're using it underwater, make sure you change to that setting.Yes, if you read the whole owner's manual, it sounds pretty silly, telling you it's waterproof in one place, and not to get it wet somewhere else!  If you're out of the water, waterdrops on the lens (rain, waterfall mist) will show up as a blur on your shot, so keep that in mind.  Decent battery life so far.  My husband shot a FANTASTIC panorama of the Waimea Canyon using this camera, and with the frequent rain on Kauai, it was nice to be able to keep my more expensive camera safe without missing photo opportunities.After each snorkling trip we first rinsed the camera, then let it sit in fresh water for several minutes.  Even though I never spotted sand on the camera, there would be some in the sink after soaking.  We then let the camera dry completely before opening it up to download pictures or charge the battery.  I would find a few tiny water drops when I opened it up, but these were always just *outside* the seal.  I would dry these up immediately and make sure there was no moisture in the area before closing the camera back up.I left Kauaii with pictures and video of me swimming with sea turtles . . . I have no complaints!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!!
Reviews.Author: Tyler Oliva
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera! I brought it with me while I went to Bermuda. It's pictures aren't as sharp or amazing as some other compact cameras, but this definitely did the job well. I took about 700 pictures throughout the seven day trip, and a good chunk of them were underwater pictures. I never had any problems about water damage during the trip, and when you set the camera to underwater mode its shots are excellent! If you see some water inside the little latch that conceals the battery/SD card, don't be scared. The water leaks in, but stops at the rubber strip so it will not enter in. It freaked me out the first time I saw it, but it's not a problem.As I said before, this camera takes excellent photos, and has a decent zoom for a fixed lens. The colors are vibrant, and the shutter speed is quick, so you're not losing your subject before the picture is taken. The underwater pictures are great. That is, if you put the camera on the underwater mode. They look very nice, and the colors of all the coral really pop and sometimes you get one shot that shows just about every detail of your subject. But it does not float, so I would get a loop that will allow it to float, just in case you drop it by accident underwater. On the other had, the video isn't so amazing. Well, I suppose the video is okay but the audio is horrible! The wind is so loud that most of the time voices can't or are barely heard, and if you talk too loud then it'll be that irritating scratchy sound.The battery is intermediate, and if you're an extreme power saver like me and turn it off right after you've taken your picture, it lasts a good amount of time. The interface is very easy to use and the camera has many features. And while going through the tunnels in Fort St. Catherine, the flash blinded some people, and lit up the whole tunnel for a good picture. The flash is very bright, probably better than may Nikon Coolpix S6000.Overall, I would recommend this camera to anybody, and it can definitely take a beating. It never broke down on me (like some reviews say) and it did everything I put it through. Great camera at an even better price.

Reviews.Title: Did not survive snorkeling
Reviews.Author: C. Adamson
Reviews.Content: This camera seemed perfect for a week of light snorkeling, but it did not last long.After one day used snorkeling, the screen died. A day later the camera would not power up at all.We had been adhering strictly to the water usage guidelines for the camera (double latched, surface use only, short periods of water use.)If you are still considering this camera, note the following:- There is a water seal which the instructions say should be replaced by a dealer every year, and a fee applies- In water, must be used no deeper than 16 feet and no longer than 120 minutes- The manual says that the product passed internal tests for water resistance but it is not guaranteed

Reviews.Title: A good purchase
Reviews.Author: Eric Dos Santos "Q"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera on a recent trip to Florida and so far, I like it quite a bit.Cons after a couple of months of use:1. No lens cap/closure. This means that almost every time I reach into my pocket/camera bag or whatever to take it out, I get greasy fingerprints on the glass in front of the lens unless I am being extra careful.2. I don't like the fact that I have to enter the menu constantly to adjust settings. I am used to shooting on a DSLR and I like to take control of the way my camera is handling pictures. The menu in this camera is complicated enough as to make this unrealistic. this is a minor problem, though, considering that this is realyl intended to be a point and shoot camera, and not some fancy-pants artistic/professional camera.

Reviews.Title: very satisfied
Reviews.Author: GGS
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for the water protection part only and it fulfills all my water expectations, great pictures and great videos. Only negative thing I have is the battery live which seems to be short.

Reviews.Title: Nice Pics but Camera itself will not last long but cheaper than disposables
Reviews.Author: AirborneAllTheWay
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a trip to the coral reefs of the FLorida Keys. I shot many pics and videos and have to say that most of them came out very well. I really do like the digital video feature. I zoomed in and out while underwater and have a couple of videos that are up to 2 minutes in length. Two other people on our trip also had the same XP50 and one had an XP30. By the end of the trip all of our cameras began to show condensation under the back monitor screen; the XP30 was in the poorest shape - it also had condensation around the lens. My thought is that its door locking system isn't quite as tight as the XP50. I would also be willing to believe you cannot go even near the 16' limit recommended by the makers. WHen snorkelling, it is a little tough to make out good detail on the monitor. After each trip, I washed it with soap and water to get the salt and sunscreen off of it and it shined and looked like new each time. Another friend used an Olympus and he reported no problems above or below the water. His Olympus was in the $300 range. Also, with the price of the XP50 and the amount of pics and vids I took, with a discount, its not bad but you know it will not last very long. Now I have digitals that I can manipulate any way I choose, rather than hard copies and negatives. Think about it, using 6 disposables along with their developing you have already wrapped up $120-130. All-in-all, buying this camera is a 50/50 shot that it will work more than a week or two under heavy useage. I liked the pics and vids but do not trust its longevity.

Reviews.Title: Its an ok camera, not great.
Reviews.Author: Charlie B
Reviews.Content: Image quality is so-so, but you get the weather/water proof feature.I needed that feature - lots of outdoor use in wet conditions, so am satisfied with the images.Images tend to be soft due to the over use of noise reduction.  Fine detail is lacking, and the images take on a fairly "painted" look when examined at higher magnification.All the small cameras, similar to this one... do that.  You just have to choose features or image.  I chose features, and no complaints except for image quality.

Reviews.Title: Worst Camera Ever
Reviews.Author: Lynn
Reviews.Content: This is the worst point and shoot camera I have ever had. I previously had a Canon Powershot and loved it, you could take pictures anywhere on auto and the pictures were clean and clear. This Fuji doesn't take action shots, night time shots or pictures in low light even if you take it off of auto and set it in the correct mode. I've wasted a whole six months of my life trying to play with the camera instead of taking pictures of my kids birthdays, vacations, etc. I do not recommend this camera if you are like me with 4 kids and not alot of time to put into your camera and how it works.

Reviews.Title: niki
Reviews.Author: niki
Reviews.Content: Love this camera! I have not tested out the water feature yet, but I no longer need to worry about the camera getting splashed by the kids at the lake house. Pics turn out great and good quality. It is quick to take pics and has the best night quality pics than any camera I have ever owned.

Reviews.Title: Very dissatisfied
Reviews.Author: Richard C. Mueller
Reviews.Content: Fuji XP50 is not a very good camera.  Pictures not of good quality and blurry.  When in video mode, the camera does not re-focus when you zoom in or out...only stays on the same focus where you started.  Underwater screen is difficult to see....it's like a huge airpocket that you just see white/silver but not the screen with the image you are looking at.I do not recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Don't get.
Reviews.Author: gdog max
Reviews.Content: Would not get this camera.  I took it for a week long snorkel trip.  the next to last day, the screen started to show condensation. The last day the camera didn't work.  I double checked and the seal around the battery still works.  The screen was the failure part.  This is the second camera I have bought and both have failed.

Reviews.Title: Camera dies
Reviews.Author: Macd123
Reviews.Content: On my second use of this camera while snorkeling it died - black screen and won't charge.  This is an embarrassing product and I feel like I got taken for a ride.  Buy a cheeseburger instead it will give you much more satisfaction.

Reviews.Title: So disappointed!
Reviews.Author: JessNav
Reviews.Content: I treated myself to this camera just before Christmas 2012, the picture quality was good, there was many different modes to choose from and I found it easy enough to use. I first took it in the sea with me in May time, it worked fine but I did notice the zoom buttons became quite stiff or sticky. It came in the sea again with me in July and in the swimming pool, again it worked fine and had no problems. Sadly on its last trip in the sea in September in Greece it died on me!!  I noticed the lens looked like it had condensation on it, when I tried to turn it on, the light kept flashing green, orange, red and eventually it just stopped doing anything altogether. When I opened it up the battery was soaked, I was so disappointed! I won't be asking for a swap, I want a refund :(

Reviews.Title: BUYER BEWARE
Reviews.Author: JBoz
Reviews.Content: I always read the reviews, both positive and negative, before making a decision to purchase a product.  I had read the negative reviews on this product but the deal was so good I decided to purchase anyway. I figured with a one year warranty I would be okay.  This product worked once!  After paying $10.00 to return to Fuji warranty department I was told the issue was a bent pin and was not covered under warranty and the repair would cost more than the camera!

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: Curst Saden
Reviews.Content: This camera kinda has a screwy reputation on here, but I think it's a wonderful machine as long as you take good care of it.  It makes great shots and videos above water as well as underwater.  It can safely stay underwater for half an hour, after that you want to get it out and gently dry it off.  It can also dive up to sixteen feet (I rarely go past eight so it was fine for me).  The annoying thing is that ZERO sand can get inside the camera, so it's a little tricky having it on the beach but if you are careful it'll be ok.The camera itself has numerous shooting modes, including but not limited to landscapes, sunsets, snow, beaches, and three types of underwater shooting (you really only need two...)  The battery is pretty solid, it only dies quickly if you film a lot of videos in succession.Overall I recommend this camera, especially to people who like to shoot underwater.  I got amazing underwater pictures of fish and a sea turtle on my trip to Hawaii!  It's a good buy.

Reviews.Title: Perfect, for a low price I got a very good camera
Reviews.Author: RODOLFO CESAR MATO AMORIN
Reviews.Content: I took very good shots and movies underwater. The battery did not last very much. Recommend to get an extra one.

Reviews.Title: DONT WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY!
Reviews.Author: Ran
Reviews.Content: I have owned three of these and they all were worthless. The first had bad quality pics. The second leaked the 2nd time I used it and the third would shoot less than 100 pics per battery recharge. All Fuji Finepix XP series cameras are junk.

Reviews.Title: I had the green one
Reviews.Author: Emily J. Dana
Reviews.Content: First thing I wanna say, I live in Rockawy, NY. Which means beach and pool all summer long. All day long.I had the first version of this, and this one. I took them everywhere, I never had issues with the photos or anything.The reason I had to get a replacement for the first one was because I fell off a bench taking a photo of the sunset (I was like, 13) and broke the battery compartment cover off. But the camera still worked! As long as I used duct tape to keep the battery in.So then the green one, this model... I loved it. Not quite sure what the 1 star reviews are saying, my little sister left it in the pool overnight (in the bottom of the pool, mind you), I took it to the beach, underwater, in the ocean... and it still worked. Perfectly. Then someone stepped on it at a party and it never turned on again. But the original one, the one with the missing battery cover, that one still worked perfectly, so I went back to that. And had a duct taped camera in all those myspace mirror shots.

Reviews.Title: It's not bad.
Reviews.Author: ORDucks#1
Reviews.Content: short and sweet. it takes decent pictures. the auto scene recognition works 90% of the time. It does a really good job at face recognition. battery life is ok but play it safe and have a spare with you if you plan on taking lots of photo's. i get around 200-300 photo's on a battery depending on if i'm using the flash.  one big negative - the flash has a habit of reflecting off my fingers and whiting out photo's. they have the black rubber grip on the front for your fingers but using it will cause that problem.

Reviews.Title: If I could give it less than 1 star, I would
Reviews.Author: A. PRESS "sunburstGirl"
Reviews.Content: Don't buy this camera.I wish I'd listened to the other negative reviews about the so called waterproofness of this camera.  It's sold as such, but in reality it isn't.This camera failed the very first time I used it underwater.  I managed to get off one test shot, but then that was it.  The camera died and hasn't shown the slightest sign of life since.When I was using it out of the water, both on a rainy day in Cambodia and a humid day in a Thai rainforest, the camera performed pretty well, and that's what the half a star I'd like to give it is for.  The primary reason I bought it, though, was to use underwater whilst snorkeling (this was our honeymoon trip), but that was not to be and now I have no pics at all of that part.  Disappointing to say the least.The bit that seems to have failed is the battery compartment door.  It comes with two locks on it, both of which were in the fully locked position when I went into the water.  Now however, having been back a little while and finally getting round to complaining to Fuji, I can see green areas of corrosion inside the battery compartment.I've read accounts other people have posted about getting nowhere with Fuji, who have a tendancy to write back and say it's not down to them as water ingress killed the cameras, so I'm not holding up a great deal of hope in getting any redress, but I'll try!

Reviews.Title: Too complicated
Reviews.Author: E. Berg
Reviews.Content: I thought this was going to be a fun little camera to have; living in the Pacific Northwest, a waterproof camera is a great thing to have - it rains a lot here!  :-)  But the complicated menus made me give up on this camera after just a few days - I am not one easily intimidated by electronics, but this one I found little patience for.I loved the green look (NOT because I am into the politically correct "green" movement - it was just a pleasant color) and the heavy feel of the camera; it felt sturdy and it took pretty pictures and recorded clear videos.  But having to go through several steps to change even the simplest setting was something I decided I did not want to do.  I missed having more outside knobs and dials to use, which, of course, a waterproof camera wants to have fewer of; I thus decided I did not need a waterproof camera.I also thought the lens was in a rather awkward place in the top left corner.  I found myself having to move my left hand down, and thus found the camera somewhat uncomfortable to use.The editing software installed on the camera seemed good.  The flash, however, used in my medium sized living room in the evening, was too bright.  Taking pictures in that same room without a flash worked great, though, so no real need for the flash when the room was well lit by my lamps.Something else that bothered me was the lack of catching movement and "freezing" it - my two older cameras can do that without any problems - this one could not.  Perhaps there was a setting I did not find that could have corrected this?  I tried to find out, but could not in the time I familiarized myself with this camera.However, for somebody who wants a waterproof camera, it will be a great pick; the pictures and video's were great, but I returned it anyway.  Based on the short time I had it, I would, however, recommend it for somebody looking for a waterproof and somewhat funky looking camera.  It just wasn't for me.

Reviews.Title: Failed twice
Reviews.Author: Jeff.b
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera twice in one week after losing my Kodak Playsport in the ocean. I bought at Walmart in FL and took to the beach.  Pictures were good in light and under fresh water.  Terrible night shots.  Most importantly, the camera failed completely the first time and continually froze on my second purchase.  Way too many other cameras out there.  Do not waste your money

Reviews.Title: it really can get wet!
Reviews.Author: photonut
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera specifically because during our vacation we were going tubing down the Delaware River in New Jersey and I wanted pictures.  This camera has gone in a pool, in the river, in a lake and in the ocean.  The pictures turned out good and the camera still works!  So it served the purpose for which it was purchased.  I haven't read the instruction manual (yet:) so some of the settings are still a mystery.  Shutter time is pretty good, but sometimes I have to push the button a couple of times.  Next they need to invent a cloth that stays dry so I can wipe the drops of water off the lens!

Reviews.Title: Great rugged little beach vacation camera
Reviews.Author: undeuxtrois123
Reviews.Content: Can't beat the price/functionality combination in my mind.Bought it at Costco in Hawaii ahead of a raft trip, and now I have underwater movies and pool shots.It takes good pictures too.  What's not to like?

Reviews.Title: Great pictures.
Reviews.Author: Scott W Haney
Reviews.Content: This camera has become my everyday camera, not just for underwater shooting.  It not only takes awesome underwater photos, it also takes great photos inside and outside in various lighting.  Highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: A new seal recommended EVERY year
Reviews.Author: Bob
Reviews.Content: Paid $140 at Navy Exchange.Claims Waterproof 16ft, Shockproof 5ft, Freezeproof 14f, and Dustproof, with 5X optical zoom.In the box: Camera, battery, battery charger, USB cable, wrist strap, software CD, basic manual, and a "Keeping the Camera WaterResistan" sheet (monster big sheet (20"x16") with one note and two steps, but those three simple items are repeated in way more languages than I need).The "Basic Manual" is VERY basic indeed, coming in at 13 5x5" pages and about a size 5 font. If you go to the Fujifilm you can download "the manual they should have supplied in the box", which is a BIG improvement over the one provided on purchase. Found at: [...] (Might be a good idea for potential buyers to review prior to purchase).After charging up the battery for the first time, I loaded it into the camera and sealed it up. Upon turning it on, it came up with the set-up screen. About a moment later, the screen switched to an alert indicating the battery compartment was not fully sealed. Looking at the two latches they appeared properly secured and I also gave both of them an extra press to make sure. The alert stayed on screen, so I started pressing buttons, until when I finally pressed the shutter button the alert went away and the camera switched to photo taking mode (I went back in later to update the time/date). Later, I figured out that it regularly shows this alert to help the user avoid a disaster.A note of caution: When setting the camera down, it is instinctive to not place it on its back, which could cause the view screen to get scratched, or on the front which places the lens in harms way, but trying to set it down in it's "natural" upright position is EXTREMELY UNSTABLE. There are four little legs/tabs (about 1/16" high) that prevent the camera from sitting in a stable position  If you're setting it down, your only practical options are on the back or the front. A pocket or camera bag would be preferred.Question: Does the battery charge while hooked to a computer? Nothing, that I could find, in the instructions indicate that it does.On the topic of batteries, the newer style lithium-ion batteries are excellent performers BUT they tend to have very limited compatibility. If you're on vacation, miles from any large store and your battery goes dead can you easily find a replacement? For example, my Sony camera uses the same style/size BUT not compatible battery. I really prefer the good ol' AA battery that might, in a pinch, be swapped out with some other electronic that may be at hand. And more importantly that can be found easily in just about any small shop or gas station, AND in just about any country.An interesting note found in the downloaded (not in the supplied manual) - "To ensure continued water resistance, it is recommended that you have the water-resistant seal replaced about once a year (a fee is charged for this service). Contact your retailer or a FUJIFILM-authorized repair technician for more information." I can't help but wonder how much that will cost? I could not find any further information on this topic at the Fujifilm website.The camera has a very solid feel to it, the controls are well placed, and the unit will easily fit in a shirt pocket. The functions, for the most part, are reasonably intuitive but the different modes take a while to dig through (via the menu button).At this point I've used the camera on two different days. Both times, while hiking, on very sunny bright days. Using the camera in the SR (Scene Recognition) auto mode the camera easily recognized when I needed a close-up macro shot and when I was shooting a landscape. The auto focus works pretty reliably and most shots turned out quite sharp. As for exposures, by far, most of the exposures are under exposed with a very dark cast to them and shadowed areas are extremely dark. I still have to "play" with the unit to make a fairer judgment but this will give others an idea what to expect. I have yet to test the units water proof capabilities (kinda scary).

Reviews.Title: XP does take fine pix's see my wave vid/pix
Reviews.Author: cutie
Reviews.Content: // To view this video download Flash Player (version 9.0.115 or higher)'); } } catch(err) { fp_resizePlayerSpace('cv_mo2R1EAARKNFGT7', 0, 0); } return false; } function _cv_mo2R1EAARKNFGT7loadSwf(movieID, playerVersion) { var swfLocation = "http://g-ecx.images-amazon.com/images/G/01/am3/20120510035744301/AMPlayer._V148501545_.swf";
